headline: Hot Pepper Jelly
description: This hot pepper jelly recipe makes 6 jars — great for festive gift-giving! The jelly is a deliciously spicy treat on crackers with cream cheese.

video.description: See how to make a spicy red and green bell pepper jelly.
video.name: How to Make Hot Pepper Jelly

name: Hot Pepper Jelly
recipeIngredient: 2.5 cups finely chopped red bell peppers
1.25 cups finely chopped green bell peppers

recipeInstructions.text: Sterilize six 8-ounce canning jars and lids according to the manufacturer's instructions. Heat water in a hot water canner.

Place bell peppers and jalapeño peppers in a large saucepan over high heat; stir in vinegar and fruit pectin. Bring to a rolling boil, stirring constantly. Stir in sugar; bring back to a rolling boil, stirring constantly. Allow to boil for 1 minute, then remove from the heat and skim any foam off the top.
Quickly ladle jelly into sterile jars, filling to within 1/4-inch of the tops. Cover with flat lids and screw on rings tightly.

Place jars in the rack and slowly lower jars into the canner. The water should cover the jars completely and should be hot but not boiling. Bring water to a boil; cover the canner and process for 5 minutes.

review.reviewBody: If I rate this for myself it would be a 2 or 3-star, If I rate for my wife, it would be 5-star. She does not like heat and I do not like sweet. I cut back the sugar to 4-1/2 cups and the vinegar to 7/8 cup (based on comments about too much liquid and issues with not setting up). I used 2 HUGE red bells and one HUGE yellow bell. Green bells are unripe peppers and too bitter for me so I never use those. I also added 1 large jalapeno and 1 serrano pepper to hopefully elevate the heat. Seeds were removed from all peppers because with me, seeds do not belong in a jelly. Even though I cut back on the sugar this jelly is entirely too sweet for me and the heat was not there at all (zero). Meanwhile, I'm disappointed, my wife has already gone through an entire jar herself in 2 days (we got an 8 half pint jar yield, not 6). The jelly has still not set after 2 days. I will make a variation of this again, but I will double or triple the amount of jalapeno and serrano peppers. I will also cut back on the sugar at least another additional 1/2 - 3/4 cup.

The recipe was great, but if you like heat 1/4 cup does nothing. I put in 1/2 cup and wished I had put in 1 cup. I know the heat in the jalapenos varies but I will still use 1 cup next time. Great recipe in general.

I looked at many recipes before deciding to give this one a try and I am so glad I did. The only changes I made was 3 1/2 cups combination of red/ yellow/ orange bell peppers and 1/2 cup jalapeno peppers. We like the heat. I did use a thermometer after adding the sugar and boiled to 220- degrees. It set up beautifully and was thick enough while filling jars to have the peppers dispersed nicely. The taste is amazing! Wonderful recipe. I really think getting to a true rolling boil and using a thermometer is the key! Yumm

I have been canning for 50 years and lost my recipe a couple of years ago. This one is perfect. Unlike many jellies and preserves, pepper jelly is supposed to be a soft set product. It does take a few days to set so be patient. To update this recipe to current USDA standards process the jars for 10 minutes. Delicious!
In my 2nd batch, I added drained crushed pineapple to make it quit all going to the top and stay down all the way to the bottom, and the peppers stayed with the crushed pineapple!!
I added 3 Tbs of fresh rosemary with the peppers and substituted the juice of 1 lime then filled the measuring cup with the apple cider vinegar. Amazing!!!!
My first batch was super runny. I finally figured out that adding 1 more tbls of powdered pectin and watching closely while it boils makes all the difference. Don’t let it get too hot for too long

Worst recipe I have tried in years. The jelly doesn't set. The flavor is pure vinegar. I had to re-open all my jars and re-cook it all. I had to add an entire second box of pectin and 3 cups of sugar just to get a jelly that tastes like hummingbird food. Run from this recipe. Fast and far.
I used a food processor to coarsely chop the peppers and followed the rest of the directions for processing. Looks amazing and husband approved the taste! Thanks for sharing!
I haven’t tasted it yet, so I’ll update as soon as I do. The process was super simple and the instructions were clear and easy.

I did have some license with the peppers. I used 1 cup green pepper, 4 large jalapeño peppers and 2 habanero peppers. Just enough of a bite and the sweet balances it perfectly.

I've made this several times in the last couple of weeks and it is absolutely delicious! So easy to make! The taste is bang on!!! If you add extra pectin, it will turn out. Hopefully, this recipe gets changed to include additional pectin.

Delicious! Mine set up fine. Nice and thick, I used the inverted method, and it set fine. I made mine with a kick, delicious, but pretty hot. This jelly is amazing! I doubled the recipe since I was making enough to give away for gifts and here are the amounts that I used:
-6 cups green bell pepper, chopped fine
-2 cups jalapenos, chopped fine
-2 cups apple cider vinegar
-2 packages (1.75 oz) powdered pectin (I used Sure Jell)
-10 cups white sugar

1 - Mix chopped bell peppers, jalapenos, apple cider vinegar and sure jell in large pot over HIGH heat.
2 - When it reaches a boil, BOIL for 3 minutes.
3 - Mix in sugar and continue to stir until sugar is melted.
4 - Bring to a rolling boil and continue stirring for 3 minutes. Remove from heat and set aside.
5 - Ladle jelly into jars. leaving 1/4 inch head space.
6 - Process jars for 10 minutes in hot boiling water bath.
7 - Cool jars overnight on counter and label.
8-Store in cool, dry place for up to 1 year.

Makes approximately 12 (1/2 pint) jars.

I just made this recipe today. Peper Jelly is the only thing I can every year. With that said, I used this recipe because it called for powdered pectin and I normally use liquid pectin. I have never used powdered pectin until today. 
Of course I changed a few things...First of all, I used only jalapeno pepper, 2lbs. I removed most of the seeds but left some for a little heat. Next, put all the peppers in my food processor with half the vinegar. Then I added the pepper mixture to my large stock pot with the remaining vinegar and added one box, 1.75 oz, of the powder pectin. The rest of the recipe I followed to the "T" with the exception of doubling the other ingredients...WITH THE EXPECTATION IF THE PECTIN...I only used the 1.75 oz box. I have read that some other users cant get their jelly to set. Mine worked perfect! I think the key that might be getting missed is that when you add the sugar, make sure it returns to a full boil. It takes a little while for the mixture to return to a boil. DO NOT add the sugar and let it sit for one minute...get it back to boiling. Considering that I doubled the recipe but used a single recipe amount of pectin and it worked...I think this recipe is great! I think I actually like the powder form better then the liquid. Ok... I'm going to see if I can help some of you out that are having issues with your jelly setting up properly. (watery jelly issue)
Using Pectin 101... Pectin requires 3 things. Water, sugar and acid. (Many jam makers swear the order that they are combined makes a difference. (water and sugar first, then Pectin, then acid) Making JJ's (jams and jellies) requires heat to cause the pectin to create a thick consistency. IT MUST BOIL! I think the actual temp is about 215 Deg F/101 Deg C for pectin to activate properly. Like using corn starch, if you don't hit the right temp, your molecular reaction will be weak and/or fail.
Because JJ's are usually made with fruit that contain natural sugar, acid and pectin (yes, most fruits naturally have pectin in them) making a pepper jelly is slightly different than making a fruit concoction. It is very important you do not lower or omit sugar, acid or water. There are no substitutes (Sweet n Low, etc) 
Peppers do contain water so the type, production method and time of year they are harvested will dictate how much water is in the peppers and thus how much water will be released when they are cooked. (This affects cooking time) 
Chilled spoons: Keep 1/2 a dozen tasting spoons in the freezer while you are boiling down your pepper JJ. When you think it might be ready, grab a chilled spoon, dip it in your mix and then pop it back in the freezer on a small plate for a few mins. Too watery? Keep boiling! Keep testing until the taste is balanced
